1115884894926921728.text:
Lookout is a company with thousands of users, which gives them incredible visibility into what bad actors do on Android. 

.@swborders is a volunteer group of a handful of very skilled researchers with practically no “telemetry”—if you’ll allow me the threat Intel jargon.

1115884893534343169.text:
As I understand, both @swborders and @Lookout found the malware independently. I have a feeling that it’s not as rare as some people think and it’s likely similar to what happens in journalism, where multiple reporters know of a scoop or get the same tip. 

But...

1103027549125443584.text:
Companies get things wrong all the time. And if we cover them like this, we're just doing PR.

This is why you don't see that many stories like these on Motherboard anymore. If we can't confirm or at least get a second opinion, we skip it.

1103027548341051393.text:
I've done it myself and it happens every week. Journalists cover infosec reports straight, without even trying to confirm or do any further reporting. 

This is incredibly irresponsible. How do we know these companies have done their due diligence?

1103027547430928384.text:
This is a classic infosec journalism story. You get a report by a reputable company, and you cover it. Good journalists like Dustin reach out to competitors (in this case FireEye) to get some sort of confirmation. 

Usually, however, reporters don't even bothr.
